values.alignmentText: Solid enterprise/fintech demand in Belfast; consulting and public sector roles present.
Generally good outside dense traffic corridors; occasional winter NO2/PM peaks in urban areas.
Secularization is advancing, yet denominational identities remain salient.
Low; strong legal institutions and civil society.
Contactless ubiquitous; Faster Payments; easy online banking; proof of address needed.
Dramatic coast (Causeway Coast); cold water limits swimming but superb walking/surf spots year‑round.
Active scenes in Belfast; clubs/shops; university conventions (e.g., Q‑Con) draw crowds.
Part‑time funded pre‑school; Tax‑Free Childcare and UC childcare support for eligible families.
Belfast and regional towns offer good playgrounds, museums, leisure centres; stroller‑friendly routes mixed.
Part-time funded pre-school places; Tax-Free Childcare/Universal Credit childcare support; statutory maternity/paternity/shared parental leave (UK-wide); details vary in NI.
Eligibility depends on immigration conditions (e.g., NRPF) and residence; work-permit holders may access Tax-Free Childcare; documentation required.
Football, rugby, GAA, hiking, cycling, angling; beach walks and festivals.
Welcoming to newcomers; strong local clubs/associations; supportive neighbours.

Lower housing/childcare costs than GB SE; energy/transport costs meaningful; value depends on location.
Yes-UK permits dual nationality.
Modest growth; services/public sector significant; investment in tech services rising.
UK mixed economy with social safety nets (NHS and benefits system).
Quality public system with grammar/secondary split; integrated and Irish‑medium growing.
Available in some mid/large firms (Skilled Worker), but fewer sponsors than GB hubs.
Lush, coastal landscapes; low industrial pollution; oceanic climate moderates extremes.
Comparable to UK averages; effective rates depend on salary mix and allowances.

Close‑knit communities, parks, libraries; sports clubs; coast/hills for easy weekend trips.
Partner work authorization depends on route; school access for dependents; documentation required.
UK statutory leave/pay (maternity up to 39 weeks paid; paternity; shared parental leave); child benefit/Universal Credit; employer policies vary.
UK statutory frameworks generally supportive; specifics vary by employer and local delivery.
Access tied to residence status and NRPF rules; employer leave policies apply; some benefits require HRT and contributions.
Practical chic; knitwear/dresses with layers; boots/sneakers; weather-appropriate outerwear.

Diverse expressions; practical/weather‑oriented fashion; modest to contemporary styles.
Small but present; indie/mobile/service studios around Belfast; ties with universities.
Legal recognition/protections present; social acceptance improving, stronger in cities.
Strong legal protections under UK/EU‑derived law; enforcement and culture generally supportive.
Contemporary UK norms; household roles increasingly egalitarian.
BRP/visa conditions; Immigration Health Surcharge for NHS access on temporary visas; GP registration; National Insurance number, bank/lease proofs; driver licence exchange timelines.
Rising winter rainfall and storminess; limited extreme heat; localized coastal flood risk.
NHS NI free at point of use; GP/dental waits can be long; good emergency care.
Immigration Health Surcharge grants NHS access on temporary visas; GP registration required; private cover helpful initially.
Domestic tuition at Queen's University Belfast and Ulster; student loans/grants; places competitive in some courses.
International tuition for most temporary visas; scholarships limited; improves with ILR/settlement.
More affordable than GB SE; rents/prices lower; supply tight in popular school catchments.
PAYE for employees; self‑assessment for some; NI/UK tax bands; council rates apply.
Free public schooling; sectors include Controlled (state), Maintained (Catholic), and Integrated; integrated/Irish-medium expanding; zoning applies.

English dominant; Irish used in education/media/culture; no barrier for English speakers.
Legal equality; acceptance higher in cities, mixed in rural areas.
Limited mainstream presence; occasional academic/activist circles.
Modernizing; strong sports culture; caregiving roles increasingly accepted.
Active meetup scene in Belfast (tech and hobbies); regional communities growing.
UK National Living Wage applies; uprated annually; purchasing power varies by region.
Good broadband/4G/5G in cities; FTTP expanding; reliable grid and payments.
Giants Causeway, Mourne Mountains, Antrim Coast; high scenic value and easy access.
Low baseline risk; winter storms and flooding can disrupt; resilience improving.
Short drives to coast and hills; abundant trails and greenways.
Live music and pub culture in Belfast and Derry/Londonderry; venues smaller than GB hubs.
Belfast and Derry/Londonderry lively (pubs/live music); smaller towns quieter; generally safe with usual city caveats.
University clubs and local dev groups around Belfast; periodic events and game jams.
Small indie/service studios; limited AAA presence.
NI Screen support and UK Games Fund; lower costs than London; publisher access largely remote.
Relaxed compared to GB hubs; manageable commutes.

Low levels by international benchmarks; robust oversight.
UK constitutional monarchy with devolved power-sharing assembly; periodic suspensions.
Social acceptance limited; discretion advisable outside progressive circles.

Limited independent options mostly around Belfast; fees moderate vs US; admissions selective.
Mixed: cities more progressive; rural areas more traditional.
Pluralistic media environment; tabloid spin exists; multiple viewpoints available.
Moderate; counterbalanced by independent outlets and UK-wide media.
Belfast good; intercity reasonable but infrequent; rural bus coverage limited.
Historically influential; trend toward secular governance; local variations remain.
Post-pandemic normalization of hybrid/remote; employers vary.

Niche; a few startups/SMEs; fewer roles than .NET/Java.
Generally safe; petty crime in city centres; low violent crime by global standards.
Controlled/Maintained/Integrated/Irish-medium; grammar pathway; secular integrated expanding.

Typical daytime ~7-14 C (45-57 F); frequent light rain/showers; lengthening daylight.
Generally stable with occasional political stalemates; daily life largely unaffected.
Centrist mixed-economy approach with devolved nuance.
Mixed economy with private enterprise alongside public services.

Visa fees and IHS significant; processing typically weeks–months; legal fees optional.
Varies with UK/NI politics; moderate overall.
Low systemic corruption; occasional local procurement/administrative issues.

values.alignmentText: Viewed as friendly and scenic; politics perceived through UK/ROI contexts.
